HILL HOUSE, NORTHREPPS, CROMER, NORFOLK. 3rd July, 1941. .: J Ly dear Patrick, I wonder whether my services juld he usefully employed now that we are in with‘Russia. You yourself know that I was in Tashkent for 14 months in 1918-19, and in Bokhara for two. These are regions very little known to our officers. Perhaps this local knowledge with a colloquial knowledge of Russian, might he useful to the country in the present circumstances. I do not think that after so many years the Soviet authorities would hear any resentment at things done during what they call the 'Intervention Period' • I would he very glad if you would pass this suggestion on where it is most likely to he taken up. I attended a course of lectures on Military Intelligence at the W.O. just before the War.■■■■ I attach a brief curriculum vitae. Yours sincerely, (Sd.) F.i.;.BAILEY.Lt -Colonel F.LV;ailey, C.l.S . Born 3rd February, 1882. First Commission 28th July 1900. Served 1 year British Infantry 2 years Indian Cavalry 2 n M Pioneers. With latter Regiment accompanied Sir Francis Younghusband to Tibet as escort in 1902 and later joined Expeditionary Force as officer of Ivlounted Infantry; served as such in fighting, including occupation of Lhasa. After Tibet Expedition was sent as Tibetan Interpreter with Exploring Expedition from Lhasa to Gartok in Western Tibet, the party eventually emerging at Simla. In 1905 sent to Tibet as British Trade Agent at Gyantse for 2^- years. In 1911 travelled from Peking to Assam across China and through a portion of South-eastern Tibet(awarded Gill Memorial by Royal Geographical Society). In 1 .. 12 , with late Captain Morshead, explored Falls and Bend of Tsangpo (Bramaputra in Tibet (awarded Gold Pedal by Royal Geographical Society, and MacGregor Medal by Royal United Service Institute). In Great War served in France, Flanders and Gallipoli (twice wounded), and later as Political Officer on Indian Frontier, Mesopotamia and South Persia. In 1918 sent to Kashgar (Chinese Turkestan) in charge of Mission for Intelligence work; went to Tashkent, then in control of Bolsheviks. Was arrested there but got away and lived for a year as Austrian prisoner of war in Tashkent. Eventually joined Bolshevik Secret Service (counter-espionage) as agent and was sent to Bokhara by them. From Bokhara travelled over desert to Meshed (North Persia). Awarded Livingstone Gold Medal by Royal Scottish Geographical Society. In 1921-28 Political Cfficer for Tibet, Sikkim and Bhutan, during which time explored portions of Tibet and Bhutan and visited Lhasa. After some political work in Central India, appointed Resident in Kashmir 1922-22 and H.B.M's Minister Plenipotentiary in Nepal.1925-28. Retired/Retired in 1938. In 192C was in charge of arrangements for tour in India of His present Majesty King Carol of Rumania, who is a personal friend. Also a personal friend of Field-Marshal Kannerheim of Finland, who has twice visited me in Sikkim and Hepal and with whom I spent some time in Finland in 1937. Languages . mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between Lieutenant-Colonel Frederick Marshman Bailey, the India Office and the Foreign Office, regarding the proposed publication of Bailey's account of his personal experiences as an intelligence officer in Turkestan in 1918-1920, the approval for which is ultimately denied on the grounds that it would be inadvisable at that time to publish a book which held the early Bolshevik regime up to ridicule.The file also contains a request from Bailey, accompanied by his curriculum vitae, that he might be considered again for intelligence work following the military alliance between the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union.A list of correspondence references contained in the file by year appears on the front cover.
